awd_titl_txt: Research Capacity Building and Communication Activity Support for Future Earth
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides core support for capacity building, communications and information technology activities of the US Hub of Future Earth Secretariat. The Future Earth program seeks to coordinate international global change research to help accelerate transformations to sustainability through research and innovation. In this role, the US Hub of Future Earth serves as a convener that helps US researchers engage in research based on the co-design and co-production of knowledge and tools designed to help develop solutions to global environmental challenges such as fresh water security, coastal vulnerability, disaster risk reduction and resilience. The program is supported by major U.S. agencies, under the interdisciplinary auspices of the U.S. Global Change Research Program. Over the past several years, the US Hub has taken on activities that directly support the USGCRP and its member agencies. These funds will be used to further engage the US research community in these developing efforts. 

The Future Earth program is organized around three major themes: Dynamic Planet; Global Development; and Transformations toward Sustainability. Under the auspices of these three themes, the US Hub of the Future Earth Secretariat will support workshops and other efforts to foster the co-design of research to enhance transdisciplinary efforts to help develop solutions for many challenging societal issues. The US Hub will also develop programs and initiatives to educate the next generation of inter-disciplinary researchers and professionals on how to integrate global sustainability with human prosperity and will actively engage the public through an extensive communication and outreach effort.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Future Earth is a global network organization advancing transdisciplinary and sustainability science. The US Global Secretariat Hub (US Hub) is one of the eight offices of Future Earth?s distributed global Secretariat, and it leads several key functions, ranging from global communications, IT and finance, to coordination of the national committees and global research networks. During this reporting period, the US Hub also hosted the Interim Executive Director of Future Earth. In addition, the US Hub leads several international programs, such as the Sustainability Research and Innovation Congress (SRI), the Anthropocene Magazine, and the Earth Leadership Program. This grant supported the communications and capacity building work of the US Hub.

 

Communications:

This grant has enabled us to maintain and continue to develop Anthropocene Magazine, which is the premiere publication of Future Earth, available digitally and in print, and the first of its kind to focus top-level science journalism on evidence-based solutions to major global change challenges. 

 

During this grant period, we worked with world-class science journalists, researchers and artists to publish over 250 articles annually online and in print, including long-form scientific contributions from some of the top science-writers in the world. Our second issue won the Council for Advancement and Support of Education Circle of Excellence Award in 2018, and had honorable mention for FOLIO EDDIE Award for Nonprofit/Association magazines in 2018. In 2020, Anthropocene won the World-Changing Ideas Award from Fast Company magazine.

 

Our ?Daily Science? section, which is collected into a Weekly Science Dispatch each week, now reaches almost 33,500 people around the world through their email. To deliver this content, we work with a team of science journalists to track the latest peer-reviewed global change and sustainability science coming out in 100+ publications - ranging from wildlife journals to medical, engineering and energy journals - and turn the best global change and sustainability science into ~200 science dispatch entries a year. In addition to distribution through the Weekly Science Dispatch e-newsletter, these stories get disseminated through the magazine?s website, through social media channels, and through repeated syndication of our stories in newspapers, including El Pais, the largest Spanish language newspaper in the world, and Quartz, a digital news service with 22 million viewers each month. 

 

In the last year, Anthropocene Magazine?s website averaged more than 130,000 unique users per month. Daily Science has been published in several languages, including French, Japanese, Portuguese, English and Spanish. Last year, we added an average of 900 new members to our newsletter list each month, and we had very high open rates for our e-newsletter (an average of 35%, compared to an industry average of 18.2%), and thus our weekly e-newsletter is received by ~34,000 people each week.

 

Over the last year, we increased the number of supporting members of Anthropocene Magazine by 7% (adding, on average, 7 members per month), and we currently have 1563 supporting members of Anthropocene Magazine. 

 

This grant also supported Future Earth?s more general communications work, such as the publication of the annual report. It further enabled communications for the 2021 Sustainability Research and Innovation Congress (SRI), which was organized in Brisbane, Australia, and online in June 2021. Communications was a critical element of this first SRI Congress as, with this event, we were still building our global audience, building the SRI brand, and generating awareness of and interest in the SRI series. The first SRI Congress brought together over 2000 participants from 100 countries, and this audience is growing.

 

Capacity Building:

 

Capacity building activities under this grant included online scholarships to support low and middle income country and early career participation in SRI2021. These grants made a difference for over 100 emerging researchers and professionals in sustainability that otherwise couldn?t have participated in the Congress.

 

This grant also enabled the organization of the Future Earth Governing Council meeting in Montevideo, Uruguay, June 2018 and the Future Earth 2020 Summit, which was the first virtual summit for the Future Earth community. That summit prepared ground for the community-led governance transition process towards a more inclusive global structure. Capacity building was a key driver of the summit. Our facilitator KnowInnovation organized trainings for the Future Earth Secretariat staff on effective online meeting facilitation.


Finally, this grant supported staffing for the Earth Leadership Program, which is a professional development course in sustainability targeted to mid-career academics. The program is about to launch its first cohort under the Earth Leadership Program, which is the most diverse cohort in the program?s history. This grant also leverages the TD Collaboratory, another NSF funded project on transdisciplinary research training, co-led by the Earth Leadership Program Executive Director Sharon Collinge.
